questions.text: Porto-systemic shunt is not seen in ____.
questions.solution:
Porto-systemic shunt is not seen in the spleen.

Increased pressure within the portal venous system may result in dilation of portal venous tributaries and reversed flow at sites of portosystemic anastomoses.

questions.text: Ejection fraction is
questions.solution:
Ejection fraction is SV/EDV.
The amount of blood ejected by each ventricle per stroke at rest is 70–90 mL. The end-diastolic ventricular volume is about 130 mL. The ejection fraction is the percentage of the end-diastolic ventricular volume that is ejected with each stroke, is about 65%.

questions.text: Which of the following is a component of cytochrome oxidase?
questions.solution:
Cu is a component of cytochrome oxidase. Cytochrome C oxidase is complex IV of the ETC.

Components include two heme groups a and a3, and copper (Cu). It is an irreversible complex.

It receives electron from complex III (Q-cytochrome C oxidoreductase). Components are Cyt b, Cyt c1. 

The final electron acceptor from complex IV is oxygen and it is reduced to water.

Note: Components of complex II ( succinate -Q reductase) are FAD and Fe-S.

questions.text: Pautrier microabscesses are seen in______.
questions.solution:
Pautrier microabscesses are seen in mycosis fungoides.

Mycosis fungoides: 

  • Mature T-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma with skin manifestations. (CD4+)
  • Skin lesions include scaling red-brown patches, plaques, and fungating nodules
  • Histological hallmark:
    • Sézary-Lutzner cells: cells with cerebriform nuclei (infolded/hyper-convoluted nuclear membrane) 
    • Pautrier microabscesses: tumor cells invade epidermis as single cells and small clusters

Sezary syndrome: 

  • Variant of mycosis fungoides
  • Leukemic seeding of blood by malignant T cells from the skin (CD4+)
  • Presents with erythroderma: diffuse erythema and scaling of the entire body

 

Image: Sezary cells with cerebriform nuclei in the peripheral smear

questions.text: A method of sterilization that involves exposure to 100 °C for 20 minutes on 3 successive days is known as _____
questions.solution: The method of sterilization that involves steaming at 100°C for 20 minutes for 3 successive days is called Tyndallization or intermittent sterilization. It is mainly used for sterilization of media containing gelatin, egg, serum, or sugar. This method may not kill spores of certain anaerobes and thermophiles.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an extended spectrum penicillin?
questions.solution:
Cloxacillin is not extended-spectrum penicillin. It is a penicillinase-resistant penicillin.

Extended-spectrum penicillins have greater activity than penicillin against Gram-negative bacteria because of their enhanced ability to penetrate the Gram-negative outer membrane.

Extended-spectrum penicillin are:

  • Aminopenicillins: Ampicillin, Amoxicillin (Option A)
  • Carboxypenicillins: Carbenicillin, Ticarcillin (Option C)
  • Ureidopenicillins: Piperacillin, Mezlocillin (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for the rebound effect seen with carbon monoxide poisoning?

choices.text: Binding of carbon monoxide to myoglobin
Binding of carbon monoxide to hemoglobin
Conversion of hemoglobin from T state to R state

questions.solution:
Rebound effect in carbon monoxide poisoning is due to binding of carbon monoxide to myoglobin. 

About 15% of CO present in extracellular tissues combines with myoglobin. A rebound effect with delayed return of symptoms is due to late release of CO from myoglobin with subsequent binding to hemoglobin.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a hematoma of the pinna.

It is a collection of blood between the auricular cartilage and its perichondrium. It is often seen in boxers, wrestlers and rugby players due to blunt trauma.
Extravasated blood may clot and then organize, resulting in a typical deformity called cauliflower ear (pugilistic or boxer’s ear). It is treated by aspiration and tight pressure dressing.

Note: Exostosis is also known as surfer’s ear.

questions.text: A tribal farmer, presented with a three-day history of right eye redness with pain. He had spent the prior week trekking up a mountain in order to travel to the nearby town and takes such trips frequently. The following lesion was observed on examination. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of right eye redness with pain, and findings of a raised whitish-yellowish lesion surrounded by mild erythema, points toward a likely diagnosis of pinguecula. A history of trekking, along with chronic sunlight exposure as a farmer, acts as a risk factor because it increases the exposure to the stronger UV radiation in the mountains.

Pinguecula has a fatty appearance and is usually bilateral. They are more often located nasally than temporally. It has horizontally oriented areas of bulbar conjunctival thickening that adjoin the limbus in the palpebral fissure area. They are associated with a 2- to 3-fold increased incidence of age-related macular degeneration. It is seen in most eyes by 70 years of age and in almost all by 80 years of age.

Pingueculitis responds to a brief course of NSAIDs or topical corticosteroids. Simple excision may be warranted in rare cases, wherein pingueculae may be chronically inflamed or cosmetically unsatisfactory.

questions.text: All of the following are pillars of primary health care except:
questions.solution:
Health education is an element of primary health care, not a pillar.

Related Pearl: Elements and Principles of Primary Health Care

A. Elements of Primary Health Care

(Mnemonic: ELEMENTS)

  • Education about health problems and their prevention and control
  • Locally endemic diseases – prevention and control
  • Essential drugs
  • Maternal and child health care
  • Expanded programme of immunization against vaccine preventable diseases
  • Nutrition and proper food supply
  • Treatment of common diseases and injuries
  • Safe water and sanitation

B. Principles/Pillars of Primary Health Care

  • Equitable distribution
  • Community participation
  • Intersectoral coordination
  • Appropriate technology

questions.text: While conducting a screening camp for coronary heart disease, you encounter the following people. Who among them is at the highest risk for developing this disease?

choices.text: A person who is competitive and ambitious
A person who is calm and relaxed
A person who tends to suppress their emotions
An introverted person with negative affectivity

questions.solution:
A person who is competitive and ambitious is said to have a type A personality. Such people are more prone to develop coronary heart disease (CHD). Personality type is a non-modifiable risk factor for CHD.

Risk factors for coronary heart disease are:

  • Modifiable:
    • Cigarette smoking
    • High blood pressure
    • Elevated serum cholesterol
    • Diabetes
    • Obesity
    • Sedentary habits
    • Stress
  • Non-modifiable:
    • Age
    • Sex
    • Family history
    • Genetic factors
    • Personality 

Option B: A calm and relaxed person is said to have a type B personality.

Option C: A person who tends to suppress their emotions, especially negative emotions, is said to have a type C personality.

Option D: A person with negative affectivity and social inhibition is said to have a type D personality.

questions.text: All are true about the condition that is diagnosed by the given ECG except:

choices.text: Can be seen in asymptomatic individuals
Caused by an abnormal accessory pathway

questions.solution:
The given ECG is suggestive of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (WPW). Its prevalence decreases with age.

The classic ECG features in WPW are as follows:

  • A shortened PR interval (typically <120 ms)
  • A slurring and the slow rise of the initial upstroke of the QRS complex (delta wave)
  • A widened QRS complex (total duration >0.12 seconds)
  • ST-segment–T wave (repolarization) changes, generally directed opposite the major delta wave and QRS complex, reflecting altered depolarization

Related Pearl: Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome

Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome (WPW) is characterized by an abnormal accessory pathway in the heart leading to arrhythmias.

Pathology- Born with an accessory pathway, the bundle of Kent which connects the atria and ventricle. The electrical impulses from the SA node reach the ventricles earlier via the accessory pathway as there is no AV nodal delay in this pathway. This leads to the preexcitation of the ventricle and initiation of ventricular contraction. This ventricular contraction is prolonged when the impulse via the AV nodal pathway reaches the ventricles.

Most common location of the accessory pathway- between the left atrium and free wall of the left ventricle

ECG changes:

Shortened PR interval- because of the early initiation of ventricular depolarization

Prolonged QRS duration- because of the AV nodal impulse reaching the ventricles after the aberrant impulse.

Delta waves- slurred upstroke of QRS complex

questions.text: A patient presents with polyuria and increased thirst. Investigations reveal hypercalcemia. What could be the cause of polyuria in this patient?
questions.solution:
Metabolic derangements like hypercalcemia and hypokalemia lead to the production of large amounts of dilute urine by causing nephrogenic DI.

Options C & D: Primary polydipsia is of three types:

  • Dipsogenic – Due to inappropriate thirst.
  • Iatrogenic – Due to an increase in fluid intake due to its presumed health benefits.
  • Psychogenic – Due to psychosis or obsessive-compulsive disorder.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is useful for the assessment of intestinal mucosal function in a patient presenting with symptoms of malabsorption?
questions.solution:
D-xylose test is useful for the assessment of intestinal mucosal function.

D-xylose is a monosaccharide that is directly absorbed by the intestinal mucosa without undergoing enzymatic digestion.

The test is performed by administering 25g of D-xylose orally followed by the collection of urine 5h later. The test is considered abnormal (positive) if urinary D-xylose is <4.5g. A positive D-xylose test indicates abnormal small intestinal mucosa.

Related Pearl: Investigations in Malabsorption Syndrome

questions.text: Which is the most common cause of lung abscess?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of lung abscess is aspirated oropharyngeal secretion.

Lung abscess represents necrosis and cavitation of the lung following microbial infection. They are broadly divided into two categories:

  1. Primary lung abscesses: usually arise from aspiration, often caused principally by anaerobic bacteria (most common)
  2. Secondary lung abscesses: arise in the setting of an underlying condition, such as a post-obstructive process (e.g., a bronchial foreign body or tumor) or a systemic process (e.g., HIV infection or another immunocompromising condition)

questions.text: Paralytic ileus is a type of:
questions.solution:
Paralytic ileus is a type of adynamic obstruction.

Paralytic ileus is an adynamic obstruction in which there is a failure of transmission of peristaltic waves secondary to neuromuscular failure (i.e., in the myenteric [Auerbach’s] and submucous [Meissner’s] plexuses). Since there are no rigorous contractions, there is no colicky pain.

Clinical features :

The resultant stasis leads to the following:

  • Accumulation of fluid and gas in the bowel
  • With associated distension: marked and tympanitic
  • Vomiting (effortless)
  • Absence of bowel sounds
  • Absolute constipation
  • Paralytic ileus takes on clinical significance if any of the following are observed at 72 hours after laparotomy:
    • No return of bowel sounds on auscultation
    • No passage of flatus
  • Colicky pain is not a feature
  • Radiologically, the abdomen shows gas-filled loops of the intestine with multiple fluid levels (if an erect film is felt necessary)

Treatment:

  • Paralytic ileus is managed with the use of nasogastric suction and restriction of oral intake until bowel sounds and the passage of flatus return.
  • Electrolyte balance must be maintained.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common method of diagnostic investigation in patients suspected to have hypernephroma?
questions.solution:
The most common method of diagnostic investigation in hypernephroma or renal cell carcinoma is a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis. Characteristic features of RCC on CT scan include:

  • Enhancement of the lesion after injection of IV contrast
  • Thickened irregular walls
  • Thickened or enhanced septa within the mass or multilocular mass

CT scan has replaced IVP and ultrasound as the radiological modality of choice to evaluate renal masses.

MRI can be performed for diagnosing poorly characterized renal masses on CT or if a CT scan is contraindicated (in case of allergy to IV contrast). It also helps in defining tumor extension into the renal vein or IVC. 

The below image shows a cystic tumor involving the left kidney suggestive of renal cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A pregnant diabetic woman on oral hypoglycemic agents (OHAs) is shifted to insulin. Which of the following is false regarding management of hyperglycemia during pregnancy ?

choices.text: Metformin crosses the placenta and has teratogenic effects on the fetus
Insulin does not cross the placenta to a measurable extent
Tolbutamide crosses placenta and has teratogenic effects on the fetus
Metformin crosses the placenta but has no teratogenic effects on the fetus

questions.solution:
Metformin crosses the placenta. However, no teratogenic effects have been observed as yet.

Insulin is the preferred treatment in gestational diabetes mellitus because it does not cross the placenta to a measurable extent (American Diabetes Association).

Tolbutamide crosses the placenta and is teratogenic. Amongst sulfonylureas, glyburide has been used and no teratogenic effects were seen on the fetus.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient came with a history of fatiguability and constipation for the past 1 year. She has a history of multiple blood transfusions after delivery 4 years ago. She has had a lactational failure and never regained her periods after the delivery. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in a woman with lactational failure and postpartum amenorrhea, now presenting with fatiguability and constipation is Sheehan syndrome. A history of multiple blood transfusions after delivery indicates major obstetrical blood loss, which resulted in pituitary ischemia which lead to this condition.

Sheehan syndrome refers to panhypopituitarism occurring as a result of pituitary ischemia and necrosis following massive obstetrical hemorrhage.

The most severe form presents with shock due to pituitary apoplexy. It is characterized by a sudden onset headache, nausea, visual deficits, and hormonal dysfunction due to acute pituitary hemorrhage or infarction. Less severe forms present with anovulation and amenorrhea.

Damage to specific pituitary cell types leads to lactational failure, loss of axillary and pubic hair, and symptoms of hypothyroidism or adrenal insufficiency. Prolactin deficiency is most commonly encountered, but adrenal insufficiency is the most life-threatening complication. Hence, the adrenal function should be immediately assessed if there is any suspicion of Sheehan syndrome.

Option B: Hypothyroidism can present with vague symptoms such as fatiguability, constipation, and amenorrhea. However, postpartum hypothyroidism usually presents 4-8 months after delivery after a thyrotoxic phase with palpitations and thyroid enlargement.

Option C: Premature ovarian failure presents with menopausal symptoms. It is due to primary ovarian dysfunction. It is diagnosed when serum FSH levels are >30 to 40 mIU/mL on two occasions, at least one month apart.

Option D: Delayed transfusion reaction presents days to weeks after the transfusion. It may be asymptomatic or with low-grade fever. Coombs test may be positive, unconjugated bilirubin increased, and the rise in hemoglobin levels following the transfusion will be less than expected.

questions.text: A child suffering from steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome is brought to the OPD for vaccination. Which of the following is true about vaccination in this child?

choices.text: All live vaccines under NIS can be given as per schedule
All killed vaccines under NIS can be given
Only pneumococcal vaccine should be given to the child in acute phase
Live vaccines are contraindicated in the child’s sibling

questions.solution:
All killed vaccines can be given.

Live virus vaccines are administered with caution in children receiving corticosteroid therapy. They can be given to patients in whom the prednisone dose is below 1mg/kg daily or 2mg/kg on alternate days. If the patient is receiving corticosteroid-sparing agents (cyclophosphamide, cyclosporine), live virus vaccines are contraindicated.

Immunization of siblings/healthy household contacts with live vaccines is necessary to reduce the risk of infection transmission to the immunosuppressed child. Direct exposure to the gastrointestinal/respiratory secretions of the household contacts is avoided for about 3-6 weeks after vaccination. 

Minimal change nephrotic syndrome is the most common cause of the nephrotic syndrome. It is seen in ages 2-6 years and is characterized by heavy proteinuria, edema, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia. Patients are either asymptomatic or present with peripheral edema. Renal biopsy is not required for confirmation and treatment can be initiated if the child fits the standard clinical picture of nephrotic syndrome.

They show excellent response to steroid therapy with prednisone or prednisolone. A daily dose of 2mg/kg (max 60mg) for 6 weeks followed by an alternate dose of 1.5mg/kg (max 40mg) for the next 6-8 weeks is recommended.

Alternative drugs used in steroid-dependent patients, frequent relapsers, steroid-resistant patients, and those with severe corticosteroid toxicity are as follows:

  • Cyclophosphamide
  • Calcineurin inhibitors: Cyclosporine and Tacrolimus
  • Mycophenolate
  • Levamisole
  • Rituximab (a chimeric monoclonal antibody against CD20)

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department after he fell on his outstretched hand. An X-ray was performed and is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The  X-ray reveals an oblique fracture in the lower third of the radius and there is dislocation of the distal radio-ulnar joint, which is diagnostic of Galeazzi fracture-dislocation.

The patient with Galeazzi fracture-dislocation presents with pain, swelling and deformity at the lower end of the radius. On clinical examination, the disruption of the radio-ulnar joint can be elicited by pressing the lower end of the ulna. The ulna moves down and comes back like the key of a piano (piano-key sign).

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient comes to the OPD with a history significant for a mood disorder. Her moods can be charted as done in the image given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing 4 episodes of depression and 2 episodes of mania within 1 year, points towards a diagnosis of rapid cycling bipolar disorder. 

It is diagnosed when the patient has 4 or more episodes of depression and/or mania or hypomania within one year. There must be less than 2 weeks of normalcy between the episodes or an immediate shift between the symptoms with no intervening normal mood.

Risk factors:

  • Female patients
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Alcoholism or substance abuse
  • Antidepressants (if used without mood stabilizers)
  • Cyclothymia
  • Bipolar II disorder

The drug of choice for rapid cycling disorder is valproate. 

Note: If the phases of mania and depression alternate very rapidly in a matter of hours or days then the condition is known as ultra-rapid cycling disorder.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is observed to have difficulty in breathing along with bluish discolouration of his lips and fingers while playing. It improves on adopting a knee-chest position. Which is the ideal induction agent of choice used for surgical correction of the condition suffered by this patient?
questions.solution:
Ketamine is the induction agent of choice in this patient who is likely suffering from tetralogy of Fallot because it maintains or increases systemic vascular resistance and increases cardiac output.

Tetralogy of Fallot is characterized by sub pulmonic stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, ventricular septal defect and overriding of the aorta. This results in a right to left shunt through the ventricular septal defect and consequent cyanosis.

The commonest symptoms are dyspnea on exertion and exercise intolerance and develop blue skin (cyanosis) when agitated and are known as tet spells. The patients assume a sitting posture (squatting) or knee-chest position as soon as they get dyspneic, which leads to temporary symptomatic relief.

Ketamine does not aggravate the right to left shunt seen in such cases. It also does not increase pulmonary vascular resistance in children as compared to adults and is hence safe to administer in children.

Ketamine is the agent of choice in all cyanotic congenital heart diseases.

questions.text: Which of the following malignancies is most commonly associated with the paraneoplastic manifestation shown below?
questions.solution:
This image shows velvety warty hyperpigmentation on the front of the neck called acanthosis nigricans. By far, the commonest site of underlying neoplasm is the gastrointestinal tract (70–90%), and gastric adenocarcinoma is the most frequent.

Production by tumor cells of either transforming growth factor α (TGF-α) or cytokines that activate insulin‐like growth factors or their cutaneous receptors has been proposed as the pathogenetic mechanism.

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis from the X-ray given below.
questions.solution:
Achondroplasia is a congenital genetic disorder resulting in rhizomelic dwarfism (proximal limb shortening) and is the most common cause of disproportionate dwarfism.

The champagne glass pelvis is a sign in achondroplasia in which the iliac blades are flattened, giving rise to a pelvic inlet that resembles a champagne glass. The acetabular angles are flattened (horizontal) and the sacrosciatic notch is small.

questions.text: Among the following, which isotope is used in nuclear scanning?
questions.solution:
Technetium agents based on technetium-99m (Tc-99m) radioisotope are the most frequently used agents in nuclear imaging.

The radioactive technetium can be chelated to a number of different compounds to create specific radiopharmaceuticals and optimize imaging of various structures. The half-life of Tc 99m is 6 hours. It produces gamma rays of 140 keV.

Iodine 125 (I 125), caesium 137 (Cs 137), and iridium 192 (Ir 192) are used in radiotherapy.
